We will post specific downtime notices here as we schedule maintenance, however, please keep in mind that many systems will need to be taken down at least briefly for maintenance.

If you have any questions, please email sysadmins@lists.tjhsst.edu or ahamilto@tjhsst.edu.

Thank you in advance for your patience and enjoy your break!

Andrew Hamilton
Network / Systems Elf

post.title: STEMbassador volunteer opportunities
post.text:
Volunteer opportunities in Fairfax and Arlington County (other opportunities to be posted soon). Become a STEMbassador and give back to your local elementary and middle schools through tutoring and mentoring kids on weekends, evenings, 8th period, or during the summer.

  • Herndon Middle School (Herndon): Coach needed for VEX IQ robotics on Tues (5-7pm) and/or Wed (6:00-7:30) evenings until the January 31 competition. Location is the Herndon Neighborhood Resource Center in the Dulles Park Shopping Center.
  • Mount Eagle Elementary School (Alexandria): Volunteers needed to run stations on STEM night, January 15, from 6:30-8:30pm.
  • Frost Middle School (Fairfax): Need virtual/internet mentors to teach entomology to the Science Olympiad time. Times vary based on availability.
  • Lincolnia Community Resource Center (Alexandria): Tutors needed on any weekdays from 4:00pm-6:30pm or Saturdays from 10am-12pm.
  • Whitefield Community Resource Center (Arlington): Tutors needed on any weekdays from 4:00pm-6:30pm or Saturdays from 10am-12pm.
  • Washington International Academy (Alexandria): Tutors for grades 4-7 needed from 3:30-5:30pm Monday through Thursday (where possible)
  • Mini Lab events for the 2014-2015 school year: These Children Science Center sessions seek volunteers for four hour sessions at elementary schools. Volunteers must be at least 16 years old.
Email stembassadors@tjhsst.edu if you would like to participate in one of these service activities. More info about STEMbassadors

post.title: FCPSonboard - more info
post.text:
Most of the privacy concerns regarding FCPSonboard are related to the XpressConnect app. Here’s a few things you may want to know about this app:

  • The app is used to download a certificate that authenticates your FCPS credentials and puts you on the correct wireless network. Once you’ve installed the certificate, you no longer need the app and you can and delete it.
  • You have to reset your FCPS password every school year (this also resets your FCPS GAE password). You also have to renew the certificate every school year with your new credentials. Thus, after you reset your FCPS password each school year, you will also need to re-join FCPSonboard and re-download the XpressConnect app to reinstall the certificate. So you only need to have the app on your phone for a few minutes once every school year. Once the certificate is installed, you can delete XpressConnect.
  • This app is not downloaded on iOS devices-they have a different method of installing the certificate

If you need help connecting your device to the WiFi, please see Ms. Tecuci in room 14.

You also have to renew the certificate every school year with your new credentials. Thus, after you reset your FCPS password each school year, you will also need to re-join FCPSonboard and re-download the XpressConnect app to reinstall the certificate. post.title: Reporting Service Learning Hours
post.text:
Our school is now using a pilot program called x2VOL to track student service learning hours. This program will allow you to log your service hours online through Blackboard and Family Connection. X2VOL will enable you to keep track of your activities and hours as you perform them. You will need to sign on to Blackboard/Family Connection to create a profile and then you will be able to enter all your service learning activities as you go along and the program will total your hours for each year and provide a cumulative report at the end of your senior year. If you complete at least 40 hours by the time you graduate, you will receive a black cord to wear with your cap and gown. These two links provide instructions to set up your account and an overview of the program. If you have any questions, please contact Cathie Love at cmlove@fcps.edu.

See the student guide and presentation.

post.title: 8th Pd Detention is NEXT WEEK - clear your absences NOW
post.text:
The list for 8th period detention is being created this week! PLEASE CLEAR YOUR ABSENCES. To be removed you must clear your 8th period absences BEFORE 4pm on Tuesday, December 9. Many from Novembe r may still be cleared. How?

It's simple: click on the absence link from your home page, print the page and ask the teacher to sign off that you were there -- be sure to include your name, your ID, the name of the activity that you attended. Return the sheet to room 231 and you're done!

To keep from getting an absence:

  • Go to the activity that you chose -- and don't leave!
  • Make sure your teacher knows you are there.
  • DO NOT sign the bottom of a roster or attendance sheet. These names are not included in attendance and will result in an absence.
  • Don't ask a substitute to 'call you in', they can't! Absences in activities with a substitute teacher cannot be cleared!
  • Turn in your pass to the sponsor as soon as you arrive!
  • QUESTIONS? See Mrs. Burch or Mrs. Lauducci in the 8th period office (room 231)

Oh my gosh, Juniors and Seniors who STILL do not have GAE (Google Apps, @fcpsschools.net) accounts should sign up for the upcoming available sessions during 8th period, starting Nov. 12 and Nov. 19. If you are seeing this message, you have NOT properly set up your Google Apps account. Alternatively, come on a Monday or Wednesday to either side of the library at the beginning of lunch, only. You need passwords for these accounts for several reasons: items that affect your grades are being collected using the GAE accounts. Signing up for a senior lab requires a GAE account, juniors, and that process begins real soon! The FCPS password is needed to get onto FCPSmobile network. THAT is the only network you can use to access by proxy to library databases when you are using a personal device on campus. The other school networks don’t give data base access by proxy on campus. We’ll explain all of this in the session. You’ll have extra time when we’re done with the account set ups to treat as a study hall. See you then if you are STILL not accessing your GAE account. We want to help!


--Mrs. Carpenter

post.title: Computational Linguistic Olympiad
post.text: Interested in computer science? World languages? Puzzles? If so, then the NACLO competition may just be for you. The North American Computational Linguistic Olympiad is a contest in which high-school students solve linguistic puzzles. In solving these puzzles, students learn about the diversity and consistency of language, while exercising logic skills. No prior knowledge of linguistics or second languages is necessary. Professionals in linguistics, computational linguistics and language technologies use dozens of languages to create engaging problems that represent cutting edge issues in their fields. The competition has attracted top students to study and work in those same fields. It is truly an opportunity for young people to experience a taste of natural-language processing in the 21st century. The first round contest will take place on January 29. Practices will be held on Fridays starting this week during B-block in T19. Sign up for NACLO practice to see what the fun is all about! (You can still participate if you can’t come to the practices, email Miss Galanos (rgalanos@fcps.edu) for details.

post.title: TJ Email Forwarding
post.text:
TJ uses your Webmail address for communications. That’s your @tjhsst.edu address that you access with your local domain ID and password. It’s linked from Iodine’s login screen. If you need assistance to forward your @tjhsst.edu email to a preferred address, use this help:

https://livedoc.tjhsst.edu/wiki/Forwarding_your_TJ_Email

For help about your @tjhsst.edu webmail, contact mailadmins@tjhsst.edu.

ALSO, did you know that Blackboard needs you to have a CURRENT email address listed under “TOOLS: Personal Information” on the home screen? If you don’t have an updated email address there, you are probably missing out on vital communications—especially if you are a sophomore, junior or senior.

post.title: TJTED: Interview Foreign Ambassadors - country assignment this Friday
post.text:
TJTED is having a meeting this Friday B Block for the Ambassador Project, a project in which students will contact and interview foreign ambassadors to gain a better understanding of diplomacy and international relations. This Friday's meeting will serve to compile contact information of foreign ambassadors to the US, and to start assigning countries to pairs of students.

Because the interviews will take place in pairs, we strongly encourage that both you and your partner attend Friday’s meeting. The groups that help to compile the contact information on Friday will have the first pick of the country whose ambassador they will contact and interview. Preliminary research of your choices of consideration is strongly suggested.

Email TJTED at tjtechnocrats@gmail.com to get the project description handout, if you missed the interest meeting, or if you have any questions.

post.title: One Question Committee
post.text:
Hi everyone! The One Question steering committee is looking for new members to join and help with upcoming activities related to the One Question.


The One Question this year is: “How can we strive to discover and pursue our own passions despite societal norms and external pressures that would compromise our aspirations and dissuade us from pursuing them?”

The One Question steering committee is brainstorming ways to make this question more relevant and exciting to the TJ community, so participation and input would be fantastic! In the future, we are planning to invite speakers to TJ and host 8th period blocks for the One Question, so come out and help make an impact at TJ! The One Question steering committee meets on Monday 8th periods.

If you are interested in joining the One Question steering committee or have any questions regarding it, please contact Mrs. Sandstrom at ecsandstrom@fcps.edu or Brandon Kim at nodnarb44mik@gmail.com

post.title: Name the TJ Commons - Vote Now
post.text:
Students:

Thank you for nominating hundreds of names for our TJ commons. From this list of pioneers in various fields a committee of students, teachers, and administrators has narrowed the list down to the final 30 pioneers who represent various fields of study, historical time periods, and backgrounds. What each of these selections have in common is that they are pioneers in their fields and demonstrate the ingenuity and innovativeness that we strive for here at TJ.

Please vote for the 14 pioneers you would like for us to name TJ commons spaces after. Each student and faculty member will be allowed to submit their top 14 list only once. Voting will end on Oct. 31 at noon and the announcement of the winners will be made on the first week of November.

Voting will be done through your fcpsschools.net Google Account. Remember this is your Student ID Number with @fcpsschools.net at the end. If you are having problems accessing your account please see Mrs. Applin or Mrs. Carpenter in the Library or Mrs. Tecuci in room 110 for help. All students have a FCPS Google Account access.

VOTE HERE

The Nominees

JOHN BARDEEN

He was an American physicist and electrical engineer and the only person to have won the Nobel Prize in Physics twice. The transistor revolutionized the electronics industry, allowing the Information Age to occur, and made possible the development of almost every modern electronic device, from telephones to computers to missiles. Bardeen's developments in superconductivity, which won him his second Nobel, are used in Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (NMR) or its medical sub-tool magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

RACHEL CARSON

She was a writer, scientist, and ecologist who wrote many literary works to inform the public about nature, such as the book Silent Spring, in which she wrote about the dangerous effects of pesticides and tried to convince people to view the world in a different perspective. In 1963, she testified in front of Congress and called for policies to protect human health and the environment. She should be honored at TJ because she helped start the environmental revolution and changed the way we look at our world.

GEORGE WASHINGTON CARVER

African-American inventor who had the highest number of patents at his time solely for the benefit of food consumption. He was a pioneer in all fields of science: chemistry, physics, botany and biology.

VINT CERF

He is a 'father of the Internet,' and, along with Bob Khan, created TCP/IP, the Transmission Control and Internet Protocols, the basis of the technology which would help create the Internet. He has connections to TJHSST (his son attended TJ) and has won numerous awards including the National Medal of Technology, the Turing Award, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

JACQUES COUSTEAU

He once described a scientist as 'a curious man looking through a keyhole, the keyhole of nature, trying to know what's going on.' Cousteau was passionate about the sea, and I admire him for using his talents in writing and film-making to draw much-needed attention to ocean conservation.

MARIE CURIE

She is an exemplar and a pioneer for not only science, but also women in science. As the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the first person-- and only woman-- to win the Nobel Prize twice, she risked her life to bring forth breakthrough theories on radioactivity (a term she coined) and would ultimately pass away due to her extensive exposure to radiation, the epitome of scientific dedication until the end.

LEONARDO DA VINCI

The definition of a Renaissance man, da Vinci was not only famous for his art, but also for his work with anatomy, engineering, geology, botany, cartography, architecture, music, and mathematics. I can think of no better person to represent the various interests that can be found at TJ.

CHARLES DARWIN

Without Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection, biology is just a collection of facts without a unifying theory. As Theodosius Dobzhansky said in his 1973 essay: 'Nothing in Biology Makes Sense Except in the Light of Evolution'.


ALBERT EINSTEIN

Einstein was above everyone else in that he didn't simply accept other scientists' theories. After discovering that the speed of light remains constant, he spent years researching its correlations with speed and mass and eventually reached a breakthrough where he discovered relativity.

LEONHARD EULER

He and Carl Friedrich Gauss vie for the title of greatest mathematician of all time. Euler contributed more than any other person to the field of mechanics (both fluid and solid).

MICHAEL FARADAY

Michael Faraday displayed the true spirit of science even though he lacked a formal education. Faraday made many important discoveries about electricity, which helped create the world we live in today. I think we should name our commons the 'Faraday Commons' to honor this genius who so truly deserves it.

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN

Franklin was a self-made entrepreneur, turned renaissance man, turned patriot, who, embraced the best scientific and political elements of the Enlightenment. His wisdom and cunning helped give birth to the United States as a society that made real the fantasy of popular government in an organic form that would facilitate, however slowly, the incubation and evolution of ideas such as justice and scientific advancement.

ROSALIND FRANKLIN

Though Franklin was instrumental in the discovery of DNA's structure, she received no credit for it at the time. Even now, she is frequently excluded from the 'Watson and Crick' narrative. I think it's important that we recognize the contributions of those often left out of lists of scientific pioneers and that we include female scientists and Rosalind Franklin fulfills both of those criteria.

GALILEO GALLILEI

The father of modern astronomy who supported the advancement of science against the persecution of the church (there were widely different belief systems in the early 17th century).

MAHATMA GANDHI

Despite the fact that Gandhi was an extremely well educated lawyer, he was a pioneer in the field of non-violent social activism. He is a reminder to us all that we must use our education to create a difference in the world, and due to the fact that we are recieving a world-class education it is our duty to become the leaders of tomorrow and take the baton to be the next Gandhis, because there is so much change that still needs to occur.

CARL FRIEDRICH GAUSS

His contemporaries called him princeps mathematicorum, prince of mathematics. We can call a mere lobby by his name.

GRACE HOPPER

As a female pioneer in the computing field, Rear Admiral Dr. Grace Murray Hopper was a remarkable woman who contributed to the transition from primitive programming techniques to the use of sophisticated compilers. A mathematician, military officer, and computer scientist, she is an amazing role model for women. Her belief that that the statement 'we've always done it that way' is not necessarily a good reason to continue to follow the status quo is an ideal that could inspire TJ students for many years to come.

MAE JEMISON

A physician who became the first female African American astronaut and first black women to go into space.

FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT

Innovative American Architect.

JOHN LOCKE

Locke thought of ideas that incredibly affected the founding of the US. His theories on government and the social contract were vital to Thomas Jefferson when he wrote the Declaration of Independence.

THURGOOD MARSHALL

Lawyer-Changed history in 1954 when he successfully argued Brown vs. the Board of Education before the Supreme Court. Also played huge role in NAACP cases and was selected as first African-American Supreme Court Justice.

ISAAC NEWTON

All TJ students will grow to hate this guy for inventing two of the most terrifying things ever: calculus and physics. It is both fitting and hilarious that Newton's name be integrated within the very foundation of TJ.

ALFRED NOBEL

Chemist who invented dynamite, and then dedicated his fortune to the Nobel Prizes out of remorse. A reminder to students of the power of knowledge to heal and to destroy.

JACKIE ROBINSON

Jackie Robinson was the first black player in the Major Baseball League. His entry faced tremendous turmoil in the 40s from 'separate but equal' advocates, yet his participation illustrated good players, regardless of race, could enhance professional sports.

DAVID SAWYER

Dr. Sawyer was the essential person who worked with business, government, and community organizations to launch TJHSST in 1984. In only 30 years, the school has maintained an international prominence, thanks to his vision and determination as assistant superintendent in Fairfax County Public Schools.

NIKOLA TESLA

Nikola Tesla is a name forgotten in history for no apparent reason even after his research in Alternating Current, Radio, and Energy Transmission. An immigrant undaunted by failing mental conditions, Tesla exemplifies the classic 'rags-to-riches' tale, going from digging ditches at $2 a day to powering the World's Fair at Niagara Falls.

HENRY DAVID THOREAU

A scientist, a philosopher, and the inspiration for the 'Civil Disobedience' of Martin Luther King, Thoreau challenges conformity and embodies the questioning spirit we hope TJ represents. As he stated in his letter to a friend, H.G.O. Blake, on 16 November 1857: “It is not enough to be industrious; so are the ants. What are you industrious about?”

ALAN TURING

Turing is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence. He provided formal definitions for the concepts of algorithm and computation, and conceived the 'Turing Machine' which helped win WWII.

ORVILLE AND WILBUR WRIGHT

The world has changed as a result of flying aircraft. The Wright brothers not only invented through experimentation, but they were daring enough to test the prototype vehicles themselves. Great role models for inquiry at Jefferson.

MALALA YOUSAFZAI

Malala Yousafzai is a Pakistani activist for female education and the youngest-ever Nobel Prize recipient.

VOTE HERE
post.text_strip:
Students: Thank you for nominating hundreds of names for our TJ commons. From this list of pioneers in various fields a committee of students, teachers, and administrators has narrowed the list down to the final 30 pioneers who represent various fields of study, historical time periods, and backg
rounds. What each of these selections have in common is that they are pioneers in their fields and demonstrate the ingenuity and innovativeness that we strive for here at TJ. Please vote for the 14 pioneers you would like for us to name TJ commons spaces after. Each student and faculty member will be allowed to submit their top 14 list only once. Voting will end on Oct. 31 at noon and the announcement of the winners will be made on the first week of November.Voting will be done through your fcpsschools.net Google Account. Remember this is your Student ID Number with @fcpsschools.net at the end. If you are having problems accessing your account please see Mrs. Applin or Mrs. Carpenter in the Library or Mrs. Tecuci in room 110 for help. All students have a FCPS Google Account access.VOTE HEREThe NomineesJOHN BARDEEN He was an American physicist and electrical engineer and the only person to have won the Nobel Prize in Physics twice. The transistor revolutionized the electronics industry, allowing the Information Age to occur, and made possible the development of almost every modern electronic device, from telephones to computers to missiles. Bardeen's developments in superconductivity, which won him his second Nobel, are used in Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (NMR) or its medical sub-tool magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).RACHEL CARSON She was a writer, scientist, and ecologist who wrote many literary works to inform the public about nature, such as the book Silent Spring, in which she wrote about the dangerous effects of pesticides and tried to convince people to view the world in a different perspective. In 1963, she testified in front of Congress and called for policies to protect human health and the environment. She should be honored at TJ because she helped start the environmental revolution and changed the way we look at our world.GEORGE WASHINGTON CARVER African-American inventor who had the highest number of patents at his time solely for the benefit of food consumption. He was a pioneer in all fields of science: chemistry, physics, botany and biology.VINT CERF He is a 'father of the Internet,' and, along with Bob Khan, created TCP/IP, the Transmission Control and Internet Protocols, the basis of the technology which would help create the Internet. He has connections to TJHSST (his son attended TJ) and has won numerous awards including the National Medal of Technology, the Turing Award, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom.JACQUES COUSTEAU He once described a scientist as 'a curious man looking through a keyhole, the keyhole of nature, trying to know what's going on.' Cousteau was passionate about the sea, and I admire him for using his talents in writing and film-making to draw much-needed attention to ocean conservation.MARIE CURIE She is an exemplar and a pioneer for not only science, but also women in science. As the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the first person-- and only woman-- to win the Nobel Prize twice, she risked her life to bring forth breakthrough theories on radioactivity (a term she coined) and would ultimately pass away due to her extensive exposure to radiation, the epitome of scientific dedication until the end.LEONARDO DA VINCI The definition of a Renaissance man, da Vinci was not only famous for his art, but also for his work with anatomy, engineering, geology, botany, cartography, architecture, music, and mathematics. I can think of no better person to represent the various interests that can be found at TJ.CHARLES DARWIN Without Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection, biology is just a collection of facts without a unifying theory. As Theodosius Dobzhansky said in his 1973 essay: 'Nothing in Biology Makes Sense Except in the Light of Evolution'.ALBERT EINSTEIN Einstein was above everyone else in that he didn't simply accept other scientists' theories. After discovering that the speed of light remains constant, he spent years researching its correlations with speed and mass and eventually reached a breakthrough where he discovered relativity.LEONHARD EULER He and Carl Friedrich Gauss vie for the title of greatest mathematician of all time. Euler contributed more than any other person to the field of mechanics (both fluid and solid).MICHAEL FARADAY Michael Faraday displayed the true spirit of science even though he lacked a formal education. Faraday made many important discoveries about electricity, which helped create the world we live in today. I think we should name our commons the 'Faraday Commons' to honor this genius who so truly deserves it.BENJAMIN FRANKLIN Franklin was a self-made entrepreneur, turned renaissance man, turned patriot, who, embraced the best scientific and political elements of the Enlightenment. His wisdom and cunning helped give birth to the United States as a society that made real the fantasy of popular government in an organic form that would facilitate, however slowly, the incubation and evolution of ideas such as justice and scientific advancement.ROSALIND FRANKLIN Though Franklin was instrumental in the discovery of DNA's structure, she received no credit for it at the time. Even now, she is frequently excluded from the 'Watson and Crick' narrative. I think it's important that we recognize the contributions of those often left out of lists of scientific pioneers and that we include female scientists and Rosalind Franklin fulfills both of those criteria.GALILEO GALLILEI The father of modern astronomy who supported the advancement of science against the persecution of the church (there were widely different belief systems in the early 17th century).MAHATMA GANDHI Despite the fact that Gandhi was an extremely well educated lawyer, he was a pioneer in the field of non-violent social activism. He is a reminder to us all that we must use our education to create a difference in the world, and due to the fact that we are recieving a world-class education it is our duty to become the leaders of tomorrow and take the baton to be the next Gandhis, because there is so much change that still needs to occur.CARL FRIEDRICH GAUSS His contemporaries called him princeps mathematicorum, prince of mathematics. We can call a mere lobby by his name.GRACE HOPPERAs a female pioneer in the computing field, Rear Admiral Dr. Grace Murray Hopper was a remarkable woman who contributed to the transition from primitive programming techniques to the use of sophisticated compilers. A mathematician, military officer, and computer scientist, she is an amazing role model for women. Her belief that that the statement 'we've always done it that way' is not necessarily a good reason to continue to follow the status quo is an ideal that could inspire TJ students for many years to come.MAE JEMISON A physician who became the first female African American astronaut and first black women to go into space.FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT Innovative American Architect.JOHN LOCKE Locke thought of ideas that incredibly affected the founding of the US. post.title: Why Do You Love Science?
post.text: L'Oreal would not be able to create the beauty products we all use and love - shampoos, mascara, lipsticks, and lotions - without our talented scientists and engineers, many of them women. L'Oreal is looking for young women who are interested in these fields. The National Girls Collaborative Project and L'Oreal USA invites high school girls in the Washington D.C. area to share why they love science using art, poetry, and/or multimedia. Twenty girls will then be selected to attend the L'Oreal USA For Women in Science Awards Ceremony in November where they will get to meet the 5 amazing female scientists being recognized at the ceremony. Share your love of STEM today! http://bit.ly/whydoyoulovescience

post.title: Action Required: Google Apps for Education Account Setup

Important! All Juniors and Seniors must activate their Google Apps for Education and take a survey confirming that they have done it by Oct. 20.

If you are seeing this message, you have either NOT activated GAE, or activated GAE but have NOT taken the survey and must do so.

Activation can only be done from a teacher computer, and also resets your FCPS Network password (which you need to do every year to be able to use the wireless networks on your personal device). Go to any of your teachers, the library, or room 110 to complete activation.

The survey requires an FCPS Google Apps account login. It can be taken from any computer once you have completed activation. The survey can be found here.

post.title: Student Tech Assistants
post.text: Interested in helping with technology maintenance at TJ? We will primarily provide level one technology assistance and support for the computer technology equipment in the school. Typical tasks include help with tv and vcr/dvd connections, projector displays, computers not working, checking mobile l aptop carts and printers. In addition, we will assist in moving, installing, connecting and setting up equipment, installing components in computers, checking for computers/laptops in need of repair, testing and fixing network drops, etc. Looking for those with the willingness to accept and follow direction, ability to work independently, perform physical labor, work collaboratively with other students, and able to finish tasks to completion is desired. No tech experience required. Sign up on Intranet for 8A Monday and Wednesdays! Email techteam@tjhsst.edu with questions.

post.title: Homecoming Week + Dance Updates!
post.text:
The Annual Homecoming Dance is this Saturday, 8-11pm at TJ! Dance Tickets go on sale this week during lunches in the Junior Lounge/ Planetarium Lobby! They are on a SPECIAL price of $10 Monday, Tuesday, & Wednesday and will be sold for $20 on Thursday, Friday, and at the door the day of the dance on Saturday.

Reminder: Homecoming Dance Guest Forms are due Wednesday at 3:50pm to the main office or sga.tjhsst@gmail.com. Hardcopies of the form can be found in the main office or an electronic copy can be found in a previous intranet post.

Homecoming Spirit Week is THIS week (9/22-9/26). The Daily Spirit Days are as follows:

MONDAY - "Date Night" aka Dress Your Best
TUESDAY - "Opposite Day" aka Pair up with someone and dress the opposite
WEDNESDAY- "We are uNITEd" aka Group Day
THURSDAY - Class-y Night aka Class Theme Day (Seniors "Hollywood Nights", Juniors "A Knight in Shining Armor", Sophomores "Back in the Day", Freshmen "Starry Night", Faculty "Friday Night Lights")
FRIDAY - "Independence Day" aka Class Color Day (Seniors: Toga, Juniors: Blue, Sophomores: White, Freshmen: Red)

Be sure to head over to the daily pep rallies held in Gym 1 during break Monday through Thursday to cheer your heart out!

The Annual Homecoming Money Wars begins this Monday! Support your class' homecoming efforts and the "Iraqi Children Foundation" charity by donating money into lockers 615-618 (the old physics hallway i.e. middle hallway downstairs). Seniors donate to locker 615, Juniors to 616, Sophomores to 617, and Freshmen to 618.

post.title: Exchange Students
post.text:
TJHSST is seeking families to host students from the Ewell Castle School in Surry, England from October 22 – 26. Hosting an “exchange student” is a terrific experience that provides your student an opportunity to learn about the similarities and differences of students from a different country. In addition, the Ewell Castle School is hoping to arrange a return trip for students of hosting families.

Link to the Ewell Castle School website: http://www.ewellcastle.co.uk/

If you are interested or have any questions, please contact Denise Castaldo at tjhsstengland@gmail.com.

post.title: Lost and Found Objects at TJ
post.text:
Hot tips! Label the inside of your textbooks with “your name” AND “2014-15” so that our community can try to get them back to you if they get mislaid. (You don’t want to face the $$ fine if it never turns up!) ALSO, put a file onto your flashdrive with this file name: “YOUR NAME’s FLASH DRIVE” AND try to label the outside of it with a sharpie or metallic pen ( the librarians have one!) Where is our lost and found this year? It depends upon the object.
  • All BOOKS go to the library's computer lab room 242B. (Sometimes binders and school papers go there, too.)
  • Precious objects such as flash drives, eyeglasses and jewelry go to the security office.
  • Everything else like found clothing, lunch bags, and water bottles go into the bins inside Gym 2.

post.title: NEW Administrative Detention POLICY (formerly Lost and Found):
post.text:
In the first two weeks, you will have a homeroom session to LEARN ABOUT 8th PERIOD SIGN UP AND ATTENDANCE POLICIES. I want to alert you to some significant changes to 8th period Lost and Found. First, we changed the name to Administrative Detention. Second, we moved to a quarter based system. Administrative Detention remains a double block activity for students with unexcused (uncleared) 8th period absences.Periodically each quarter, a report of 8th period unexcused absences is run, and following the criteria below, students will be assigned to Administrative Detention during 8th period.

If a student gets 2 or more absences in any QUARTER, they will be assigned to Administrative Detention (AD)
If a student gets any additional absences in the SAME quarter after attending AD that quarter, they will be assigned to the next Administrative Detention.

Students will receive an email at their TJ email address letting them know and giving them a deadline to fix any mistakes with their teacher(s). If the absences are not cleared in time, the student will be assigned to a double block of Detention. Students may not be excused from Detention for any reason and failure to show up for the whole period will result in a referral to the grade level administrator.

While assignment to AD is now based upon your quarterly attendance, absences are recorded for the year and DO NOT disappear after attending Administrative Detention. Yearly totals are used for referrals (as outlined below), assigning leadership, mentorship, parking and other privileges.

PLEASE NOTE: Students will get referred to an Assistant Principal (for possible additional consequences and/or Saturday detention) if any of the following apply:

-failure to show up for the detention period

-getting 5 or more absences in any quarter

-getting assigned to 3 Administrative Detentions in the year

-getting 10 or more absences in the year

If you have any questions, please come see us in the 8th period office.

Students may not be excused from Detention for any reason and failure to show up for the whole period will result in a referral to the grade level administrator.While assignment to AD is now based upon your quarterly attendance, absences are recorded for the year and DO NOT disappear after attending Administrative Detention. Yearly totals are used for referrals (as outlined below), assigning leadership, mentorship, parking and other privileges. PLEASE NOTE: Students will get referred to an Assistant Principal (for possible additional consequences and/or Saturday detention) if any of the following apply: - failure to show up for the detention period- getting 5 or more absences in any quarter- getting assigned to 3 Administrative Detentions in the year - getting 10 or more absences in the year If you have any questions, please come see us in the 8th period office.

post.title: self-paced EPF course
post.text:
The Economics and Personal Finance (EPF) self-paced online option is now available to students during the 2014-2015 school year if it is taken as a 7th course (students in grades 9-12) or as an 8th course (only students in grades 9-11 who do not have academic intervention plans).

This course is self-paced and self-directed. All material is available on FCPS 24/7. The student must be self-motivated and able to fulfill the requirements without a teacher to direct and assist with studies. The student must fulfill the stated schedule. A teacher will not be available to explain the material. The student must have the ability to follow the schedule and take the tests when due on his/her own. No reminders will be sent to inform the student of due dates. Progress reports will be sent to students, parents, and counselors. All grades are available in FCPS 24/7 and it is the student’s responsibility to check those and stay on target. Student must have a working computer, access to the internet along with access to FCPS 24/7, and valid email addresses for himself/herself and parent/guardian. All communication will be via email and FCPS 24/7.

The cost for the course is $100 and there is only a Pass or Fail designated outcome. Students should see their counselor with the registration form and submit it no later than September 24. Note the form says September 26, but we need the extra days for processing within TJ before FCPS.

post.title: Have an invention to share?
post.text:
The Tonight Show starring Jimmy Fallon contacted the school with interest to profile student inventors on their show in November. They are looking for novel gadgets that can be used at home and the general public would find useful/entertaining.

Here are recent examples:

Part 1: http://youtu.be/53GyBD_ggpE
Part 2: http://youtu.be/lT10FOmOspg
Part 3: http://youtu.be/QfxHP2g-iUg

Interested? We invite you to make a 1-2 minute video that showcases the inventor and invention. Keep it simple - you can use the video camera on a smartphone.

Make sure the inventor says the following things:
--Name (first name)
--Age
--Hometown
--Invention Name
--How they got the idea for the invention
--Show how the invention works

Send Dr. Glazer an email (emglazer@fcps.edu) if you have something to share, and he will forward your video.

post.title: Summer School Course Requests
post.text:
Some students have been requesting to take two summer school courses. This is an exception to the normal guidelines of one course, however the administration recognizes there are mitigating circumstances where this option would create flexibility for students. A second summer course will be permitted only through an appeal conference with the principal (contact cmlove@fcps.edu for a 15 minute appointment).

Consideration will be given only to students who are taking the self-paced Pass-Fail EPF course (see previous announcement for details), have a four year plan for review (submit as an email attachment), and are taking a semester class OR plan to pursue a curricular area in depth that would otherwise not be possible without taking this 2nd summer course (e.g., four years of performing arts, paired with the neuroscience research course sequence).

Do you have a senior crush that you've been too scared to say anything about? Do you have any words or confessions that you've been too shy to tell a senior about? Would you like to send your graduating friends a sweet gift? Well now is your chance!

On May 27, 29, and 30 during lunch in Room 129. Seniors, Juniors, and Underclassmen can buy candy grams to be delivered to seniors on June 2nd. Candy grams may be anonymous and are $1.00 each or eleven for $10.00. Candy options are Skittles and Hershey Bars.

If you would like to fill out forms ahead of time, feel free to use this form. You can write all over, on the back, and attach as much additional paper as you need! If you have any special requests to go along with the delivery of your candy gram, let us know when you pay!

post.title: Library Access during JLC
post.text: Students, we really need your help. We are trying to keep the library open for your use during JLC. However, it is very sad to report that a student’s rudeness to one of our valuable JLC parent volunteers means that we’ve lost another one of them. We cannot keep the main library and library computer classrooms open during JLC without the supervision provided by our parent volunteers, so we have special “quiet study” rules for JLC mornings that really must be adhered to by all of our students. Do your part to make the volunteers feel respected, valued and thanked for their service to you while librarians are at meetings on JLC Thursdays. Please print at home Wednesday nights in case you do not get access to the library’s spaces during JLC. -- Mrs. Carpenter

post.title: TEDxTJHSST Conference
post.text:
TJ’s second TEDx conference will be held on April 25th during 6th, 7th, and 8th periods! Sign up for 8th period to hear inspiring talks by students, teachers, alumni, and parents related to our theme, “Overachieve: How do we surpass mediocrity in pursuing our passions?” 6th and 7th periods are open to class sign-up only, so ask your teachers to sign your classes up.

If you have a unique idea you would like to share at the conference, please fill out this application by April 1st. Please encourage parents and teachers to apply as well.

Please email tedxtjhsst14@gmail.com with any questions. TEDxTJHSST is an officially licensed event of TED.com. All talks will be recorded and posted on the TEDx website.

post.title: Lost and Found
post.text:
LOST AND FOUND was been moved to Friday, March 14. To be removed you must clear your 8th period absences BEFORE 4pm on March 12. Many February absences can still be cleared!

It's simple: click on the absence link from your home page, print the page and ask the teacher to sign off that you were there -- be sure to include the name of the activity that you actually attended. Return the sheet to room 134 and you're done!

To keep from getting an absence:

  • Go to the activity that you chose -- and don't leave!
  • Make sure your teacher knows you are there.
  • DO NOT sign the bottom of a roster. These names are not included in attendance and will result in an absence.
  • Don't ask a substitute to 'call you in', they can't! Absences in activities with a substitute teacher cannot be cleared!
  • If you forgot to sign up before the end of lunch, come to the 8th period office to get a pass
  • Turn in your pass to the sponsor as soon as you arrive!
  • QUESTIONS? See Mrs. Burch in the 8th period office (room 134)

post.title: Virginia High School League (VHSL) Scholarships
post.text:
Attention TJ Students: The Virginia High School League (VHSL) is offering 2 scholarships:

Allstate Scholarship: 4 scholarships: (1) Male Athlete, (1) Female Athlete, (1) Academic Activities student, (1) Courageous Achievement. Scholarships will be selected based on the following criteria

a. Candidates must have earned a Varsity letter
b. A minimum grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale
c. Involvement in other school activities outside of school (work, charities, etc)
d. Two letters of support
e. A maximum of 500-word typed student essay describing how extracurricular activities have enhanced his/her educational experience.
f. A Head and Shoulder photograph

Wells Fargo Citizenship Award: This scholarship provides $1000.00 dollars for (12) graduating seniors who wish to further their education at an institution of higher learning, including universities, colleges and trade schools. Scholarships will be selected based on the following criteria

a. Graduation at the end of the current school year
b. Participation in at least one activity offered by the VHSL
c. Contributions to family, school and community
d. Promotion of good citizenship and sportsmanship
e. Two letters of support, one from a school official and one from any other non- family member with knowledge of applicants contributions to citizenship
f. Essay (must be typed and should be between 500-1000 words) by the student
Applications should be submitted to the Career Center or Activities Office no later than March 7th

If you have any questions please contact Linda Kropf in the College Career Center or Rusty Hodges in the Activities Office

post.title: Remaining INITE tickets sale on 2/27
post.text: Our INITE lottery is complete, and we estimate 200-300 tickets remain for the March 1 show.  There will be one final sale on February 27 during JLC right outside the security office.  At 8:10am, we will ask students to draw random numbers to determine their position in line, so there isn't a need to get to school any earlier than 8am.  Tickets are $10 each, students may purchase up to 2 tickets, exact change is required, and a pledge form will be required as a promise not to resale the tickets.

post.title: College and Career Center - Engineering Week Info Session
post.text: Engineering Week is Feb. 16-22! Come to the College and Career Center on Wednesday, February 19, during either A or B Block to learn more about engineering careers from Dr. William Kilpatrick of the Society of American Military Engineers. Dr. Kilpatrick will be joined by engineering colleagues and GMU students in a discussion of the field of engineering. The speakers will also give information on engineering camps and scholarships.

post.title: College and Career Center Info Sessions
post.text:
Info Session on Summer internship with the Federal Government: A representative from the Department of Agriculture will be in the College and Career Center on Wednesday during A Block to talk about a job shadowing day in March and summer internships at the Department of Agriculture.

Info Session on Global Public Service Academies for Health: Students interested in a career in medicine, who would like to spend this summer working on public health projects in Latin America or the Caribbean, come to the College and Career Center during B Block on Wednesday to hear from TJ Junior, Sage Teasley, about Global Public Service Academies for Health.

post.title: What Can You Build in a Day?
post.text: Remember HackTJ from last year? Well, get pumped for its bigger and better successor: PilotDC! PilotDC is a 24 hour event where you can bring your idea to life with help from the area's top engineers, designers, and entrepreneurs! With lots of free swag and free food too, be sure to check out http://dc.gopilot.org to sign up and learn more! Don't know much about coding? No problem, beginners are welcome. Come and create an awesome app or website!

post.title: Updated Schedule for Semester Exams
post.text:
A message from JEFFERSON HSST

Dear TJ community,

This afternoon, FCPS adjusted the end of semester exam calendar to a two-day period so classes can meet before exams are taken. As a result of this decision, please disregard the message about schedules sent at 11:10am this morning. Our schedule moving forward, regardless of inclement weather cancellations, will be:


First day back (January 24): Blue (periods 1-4)
Second day back (January 27): Red (periods 5-8)
Third day back: Blue exams
Fourth day back: Red exams and make-up

I look forward to welcoming everyone back to school.

Goooooooooo Colonials!

Evan Glazer

post.title: Info Session on Camp Rising Sun, Friday, Jan. 17, B Block
post.text: If you’re interested in a really amazing summer leadership experience, where you make life-long friends from around the world – and tuition is free-- come to the College and Career Center on Friday, Jan. 17, during B Block, to learn about Camp Rising Sun. This is a leadership camp in Upstate New York whose alumni include former UN officials, ambassadors and well-known writers and filmmakers. Hear from TJ classmates who went last year about how it has impacted their lives.

post.title: Solar Schools Initiative Petition
post.text: Did you know that TJ has 22 solar panels on its roof? In order to expand clean energy use in the county's schools, TJ's Environmental Impact Club is petitioning the School Board to create a process for Parent-Teacher Associations to raise money for solar energy. Sign the petition here and help the environment!

post.title: Submit to Threshold!
post.text:
Do YOU want to be published? We want your prose, poetry, photos, music, and art to be featured in Threshold, TJ's Literary Magazine!

Did you know TJ also has its own writing contest? Submit prose or poetry to the theme of "Cipher" to the Shadwell writing contest! Submissions will be sent for judging to authors around the country, and the winning pieces will be featured in a special section of the Threshold magazine!

Pick up a submission form for both Threshold and Shadwell from a folder around the school or your English classroom and drop them off to the box outside Room 107 or email submissions to thresholdlitmag@gmail.com.

post.title: Military Academy Visits Monday
post.text: Interested in applying to West Point or Annapolis, or just curious to know what it’s like to go there? At lunchtime, the College and Career Center is hosting a current West Point cadet, Molly Shannon and, during 8th Period, current Annapolis cadet Josh Chester. These students can answer your questions on applying to a service academy and living in a structured, military environment. Sophomores and Juniors considering applying to one of the service academies are particularly encouraged to attend. Be sure to remember to sign up for the Annapolis session during 8th Period.

post.title: TJ3Sat - Historys First High School Satellite
post.text:
After 7 years of work, TJ3Sat is finally launching! The launch window opens at 7:30pm on Tuesday, November 19th out of Wallops Flight Facility and will be the first high school built satellite in history. To find out more about TJ3Sat, how you can view the launch, and how you can help TJ make history, come to the TJ3Sat info session Monday 11/18 during 8th period.

For more information, visit the TJ3Sat info page.

post.title: Update: UVA November 4 Trip Cancelled
post.text:
Update: Unfortunately, the UVA trip planned for the Teacher Work Day on Monday will need to be re-scheduled because we did not get enough students to participate. We will reschedule this trip for the spring, so please watch announcements from the College and Career Center. I encourage all of you who can get transportation down to Charlottesville on Monday to attend the STEM and Architecture Day event that you registered for – it should be great! Please see Mrs. Kropf to pick up your checks.

For juniors and seniors who would like to visit UVA or William and Mary on the Nov. 4 teacher work day, Scholars Travel is operating two tours that will leave the TJ parking lot early Monday morning and return early evening. The cost for each trip is $59. The William and Mary bus will leave TJ at 7:00, and a bus for participants in UVA’s STEM and Architecture Program will leave TJ at 7:30 am. Students must register online for the UVA program. Students must sign up for each trip in the College and Career Center. See your email from Mrs. Kropf or stop by the College and Career Center for more information.

post.title: TJ Runway
post.text: Come to TJ Runway this Wednesday B block and discover the role of technology (namely 3D printing) in the fashion industry and its influence on the beginning of a fashion revolution. After a brief presentation, we will be watching an Iris Van Herpen Haute Couture Fashion Show. Iris Van Herpen is a Dutch designer, and is one of the first to experiment with and incorporate 3D printing into her fashion, and to have an entire fashion show featuring only 3D printed garments. Also, in celebration of Halloween, there will be candy. Our design competition will also continue as usual! Please email any questions to tj.runway.14@gmail.com. Hope to see you there!

post.title: Seniors vs. Juniors Powderpuff Information
post.text:
All participants must:

  • submit an Emergency Care Card
  • submit a T-shirt form including a 15-letter maximum nickname and $20 (cash or check made out to TJHSST)
  • have a Physical on file.

All forms are due on November 6, 2013 to Room 151. There will be NO EXCEPTIONS since practices will begin promptly after forms are due. Practices will be held during A Blocks on the Softball field. A tentative practice schedule will be released soon. Students interested in coaching and/or cheerleading should email tjclassof2014@gmail.com.

A tentative practice schedule will be released soon. Students interested in coaching and/or cheerleading should email tjclassof2014@gmail.com.

post.title: TJ Runway
post.text:
Hello art, fashion, and tech enthusiasts! Looking for a fun outlet to express your creativity? Love art, fashion, and technology? Come to TJ Runway Wednesdays B blocks and be a designer, model, or help out with the business/technological aspects of our end-of-the-year runway showcase, no past experience necessary. Along with our yearlong design challenge, we will be conducting weekly design challenges as well complete with prizes.

Add our calendar by entering into the 'Add Calendars' tab on Google Calendar to keep track of each weekly challenge so you can decide which ones interest you. Feel free to email any questions directly to tj.runway.14@gmail.com. Hope to see you there, and there will be food.

post.title: Improving TJ
post.text:
Dear Students,

Based on your feedback and thoughtful ideas regarding ways in which to improve the TJ environment, the following items have been approved by the administration for change:

Interior Design: The Mural Club has been invited to participate in generating ideas on how to best enhance the building. All students are invited to become involved in making the school a more beautiful place.

Teachers are also encouraged to hang their students work throughout the building.

Outdoor classes: Many teachers take advantage of this as their lessons and the weather permits. However, we will communicate to all teachers that this opportunity exists and invite them to use this option.

Applauding student effort: Post cards, designed by the Arts Honor Society, will be distributed to teachers so that they can mail them home to recognize students' outstanding individual effort in all areas including character, academics, athletics, and leadership. If, however, if you are interested in submitting a design for the card please contact Mr. DeRose by November 1.

One Question Grant: You are all invited to submit a One Question Grant Proposal. Please go to the TJ Website, click on "Student Life", then click on One Question Grant, then download the One Question Grant Application.

Sincerely, Mrs. Lewis

post.title: TJ Runway Club
post.text:
Modeled after the hit Emmy nominated TV show "Project Runway", TJ Runway is the perfect club for any fashion enthusiast. Love design? You can learn to design and create clothing just like your favorite designers and brands; you can even compete in a competition similar to the TV show Project Runway. Love photography? You can create and edit a fashion photography portfolio to be showcased at our fashion show at the end of the year. Love being a leader? You could join this club to develop leadership and planning experience. Interested in modeling? TJ Runway will most definitely need models for the end of the year fashion showcase. Or maybe you could just use this activity as creative time-- a break from the normal school day. Whatever the reason, TJ Runway is a welcoming environment for beginner and advanced designers alike. All you need to do is bring your enthusiasm for creativity and your personal sense of fashion.

The interest meeting is this Wednesday the 25th during B-block. Come with your friends to learn more about the club and enjoy some great food! We hope to see you there, and if you have any questions, please feel free to email us at tj.runway.2011@gmail.com.

post.title: Academic Advocacy Guidelines
post.text:
Whenever you face difficult academic conflicts, sometimes you can use some advocacy techniques to help yourself out.  The following recommendations have been devised by the TJ leadership team:

http://www.tjhsst.edu/~emglazer/studentadvocacy.pdf

The key is to be proactive with good time management skills!  Also, make sure you turn to your counselor for additional advice.

post.title: Summer Assignments
post.text:
Congratulations on another great school year! As we prepare for the next school year, please make sure you refer to the following website for assignments that should be completed prior to the start of next school year:

http://www.tjhsst.edu/summer-assignments.php 

One assignment for all students is to read the book, “ Drive: The surprising Truth About What Motivates   Us” by Daniel H. Pink to begin thinking about the 2013-2014 One Question selected by the TJ students and teachers, “How can we maintain a passion for learning in a school system where a pronounced emphasis on achieving good grades has a tendency to reduce genuine interest in gaining a deeper understanding of subject material?”

Contact information for each assignment is posted to the website.

post.title: Ways to Improve Study Habits
post.text:
Do you want to know how to improve your study habits and possible achieve more personal academic success? Or do you want to open your mind to skills that may serve you well in the future?
